overview: Through a course of research and practice, students undertake their year-long project in Jazz & Improvisation for presentation at the end of the academic year, under the guidance of their individual supervisor.

The project outcome may take the form of a performance, exhibition, writing (poetry, fiction, script or other written literary forms), design, film, video, multimedia, CD, DVD or other new media technologies and modes of presentation.

The major project can consist of single defined project or contributions to a number of projects depending on the nature of the discipline. At the time of selection the written outline of the proposed major project or major field of study is submitted. This provides the framework for developing the lines of inquiry taken by the student and the final creative work outcome.
intended learning outcomes: display a high level of artistic practice informed by their analytical, critical and research skills;
demonstrate capabilities, as better informed, skilled and more articulate artists;
critically reflect on the work produced and the artist's role in society;
demonstrate the qualities of professional practitioners in the fine arts.

assessments.timing: End of Semester 1 (during the examination period)

assessments.description: A creative work major project to the equivalent of a dissertation. The creative work major project outcome may take the form of a performance, exhibition, writing (poetry, fiction, script or other written literary forms), design, film, video, multimedia, CD, DVD or other new media technologies and modes of presentation. Progress in this area will be monitored both by individual supervisors and a mid-year review. Mid-year reviews identify students at risk and take into account the student's progress against course engagement and project development and other areas relevant to individual disciplines.. 20000-25000 words (equivalent)

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.

Related Handbook entries: This subject contributes to the following:
Available to Study Abroad and/or Study E: This subject is available to students studying at the University from eligible overseas institutions on exchange and study abroad. Students are required to satisfy any listed requirements, such as pre- and co-requisites, for enrolment in the subject.
